class.name: PolicyTool
class.comment: for i18n
anyone can add warnings
set to true if policy modified.
this way upon exit we know if to ask the user to save changes

All of the policy entries are read in from the policy file and stored here. Updates to the policy entries using addEntry() and removeEntry() are made here. To ultimately save the policy entries back to the policy file, the SavePolicy button must be clicked.
Parse command line arguments.
split instr to words according to capitalization,
like, AWTControl -> A W T Control
this method is for easy pronounciation
use serialVersionUID from JDK 1.2.2 for interoperability
follows MW_PANEL
use serialVersionUID from JDK 1.2.2 for interoperability
class.javadoc:
PolicyTool may be used by users and administrators to configure the overall java security policy (currently stored in the policy file). Using PolicyTool administrators may add and remove policies from the policy file.

java.security.Policy 1.2
default constructor
get the PolicyFileName
set the PolicyFileName
clear keyStore info
get the keyStore URL name
get the keyStore Type
get the keyStore Provider
get the keyStore password URL
Open and read a policy file

method.name: openPolicy
method.comment: start fresh - blow away the current state
see if user is opening a NEW policy file
Read in the policy entries from the file and
populate the parser vector table. The parser vector
table only holds the entries as strings, so it only
guarantees that the policies are syntactically
correct.
open the keystore
Update the local vector with the same policy entries.
This guarantees that the policy entries are not only
syntactically correct, but semantically valid as well.
see if all the signers have public keys
check to see if the Principals are valid
check to see if the Permissions are valid
see if all the permission signers have public keys
just read in the policy -- nothing has been modified yet

method.name: savePolicy

class.javadoc: Open the KeyStore

method.name: openKeyStore
method.comment: policy did not specify a keystore during open
or use wants to reset keystore values
caller will set (tool.modified = true) if appropriate
although PolicyUtil.getKeyStore may properly handle
defaults and property expansion, we do it here so that
if the call is successful, we can set the proper values
(PolicyUtil.getKeyStore does not return expanded values)
copied from sun.security.pkcs11.SunPKCS11
throw a more friendly exception message
caller will set (tool.modified = true)

class.javadoc: Add a Grant entry to the overall policy at the specified index. A policy entry consists of a CodeSource.

method.name: addEntry
method.comment: new entry -- just add it to the end
existing entry -- replace old one

class.javadoc: Add a Principal entry to an existing PolicyEntry at the specified index. A Principal entry consists of a class, and name. If the principal already exists, it is not added again.

method.name: addPrinEntry
method.comment: first add the principal to the Policy Parser entry

class.javadoc: Add a Permission entry to an existing PolicyEntry at the specified index. A Permission entry consists of a permission, name, and actions. If the permission already exists, it is not added again.

method.name: addPermEntry
method.comment: first add the permission to the Policy Parser Vector

class.javadoc: Remove a Permission entry from an existing PolicyEntry.

method.name: removePermEntry
method.comment: remove the Permission from the GrantEntry

class.javadoc: remove an entry from the overall policy
retrieve all Policy Entries
Retrieve the public key mapped to a particular name. If the key has expired, a KeyException is thrown.
Retrieve all the alias names stored in the certificate database

method.name: getPublicKeyAlias
method.comment: first count the number of elements
now copy them into an array

class.javadoc: This method parses a single string of signers separated by commas ("jordan, duke, pippen") into an array of individual strings.

method.name: parseSigners
method.comment: first pass thru "signedBy" counts the number of signers
second pass thru "signedBy" transfers signers to array
transfer signer and ignore trailing part of the string
we are at the end of the string -- transfer signer

class.javadoc: Check to see if the Principal contents are OK

method.name: verifyPrincipal
method.comment: PolicyParser checks validity of X500Principal name
- PolicyTool needs to as well so that it doesn't store
an invalid name that can't be read in later
this can throw an IllegalArgumentException

class.javadoc: Check to see if the Permission contents are OK

method.name: verifyPermission
method.comment: XXX we might want to keep a hash of created factories...
proceed to the one-param constructor
proceed to the two-param constructor

class.name: PolicyEntry
class.comment: for i18n
anyone can add warnings
set to true if policy modified.
this way upon exit we know if to ask the user to save changes

All of the policy entries are read in from the policy file and stored here. Updates to the policy entries using addEntry() and removeEntry() are made here. To ultimately save the policy entries back to the policy file, the SavePolicy button must be clicked.
Parse command line arguments.
split instr to words according to capitalization,
like, AWTControl -> A W T Control
this method is for easy pronounciation
use serialVersionUID from JDK 1.2.2 for interoperability
follows MW_PANEL
use serialVersionUID from JDK 1.2.2 for interoperability
class.javadoc: Each entry in the policy configuration file is represented by a PolicyEntry object. A PolicyEntry is a (CodeSource,Permission) pair. The CodeSource contains the (URL, PublicKey) that together identify where the Java bytecodes come from and who (if anyone) signed them. The URL could refer to localhost. The URL could also be null, meaning that this policy entry is given to all comers, as long as they match the signer field. The signer could be null, meaning the code is not signed. The Permission contains the (Type, Name, Action) triplet.
Create a PolicyEntry object from the information read in from a policy file.

method.name: PolicyEntry
method.comment: construct the CodeSource

class.javadoc: get the codesource associated with this PolicyEntry
get the GrantEntry associated with this PolicyEntry
convert the header portion, i.e. codebase, signer, principals, of this policy entry into a string
convert the Codebase/signer portion of this policy entry into a string
convert the Principals portion of this policy entry into a string
convert this policy entry into a PolicyParser.PermissionEntry

method.name: toPermissionEntry
method.comment: get the actions

class.javadoc: General dialog window
get the Perm instance based on either the (shortened) class name or the fully qualified class name
get the Prin instance based on either the (shortened) class name or the fully qualified class name

pop up a dialog so the user can enter info to add a new PolicyEntry - if edit is TRUE, then the user is editing an existing entry and we should display the original info as well. - the other reason we need the 'edit' boolean is we need to know when we are adding a NEW policy entry. in this case, we can not simply update the existing entry, because it doesn't exist. we ONLY update the GUI listing/info, and then when the user finally clicks 'OK' or 'DONE', then we can collect that info and add it to the policy.

String name.lastIndexOf("\\\\")

\\\\server\share 2, illegal

class.javadoc: Return a Menu list of names for a given permission If inputPerm's TARGETS are null, then this means TARGETS are not allowed to be entered (and the TextField is set to be non-editable). If TARGETS are valid but there are no standard ones (user must enter them by hand) then the TARGETS array may be empty (and of course non-null).

method.name: setPermissionNames
method.comment: custom permission
standard permission with no targets
standard permission with standard targets

class.javadoc: Return a Menu list of actions for a given permission If inputPerm's ACTIONS are null, then this means ACTIONS are not allowed to be entered (and the TextField is set to be non-editable). This is typically true for BasicPermissions. If ACTIONS are valid but there are no standard ones (user must enter them by hand) then the ACTIONS array may be empty (and of course non-null).

method.name: setPermissionActions
method.comment: custom permission
standard permission with no actions
standard permission with standard actions

class.javadoc: Event handler for Edit Principal button We need the editPolicyEntry boolean to tell us if the user is adding a new PolicyEntry at this time, or editing an existing entry. If the user is adding a new PolicyEntry, we ONLY update the GUI listing. If the user is editing an existing PolicyEntry, we update both the GUI listing and the actual PolicyEntry.

method.comment: get the Principal selected from the Principal List

class.javadoc: Event handler for Principal Popup Menu

method.name: itemStateChanged
method.comment: ignore if they choose "Principal Type:" item
if you change the principal, clear the name
set the text in the textfield and also modify the
pull-down choice menus to reflect the correct possible
set of names and actions

class.name: PermissionMenuListener
class.comment: for i18n
anyone can add warnings
set to true if policy modified.
this way upon exit we know if to ask the user to save changes

All of the policy entries are read in from the policy file and stored here. Updates to the policy entries using addEntry() and removeEntry() are made here. To ultimately save the policy entries back to the policy file, the SavePolicy button must be clicked.
Parse command line arguments.
split instr to words according to capitalization,
like, AWTControl -> A W T Control
this method is for easy pronounciation
use serialVersionUID from JDK 1.2.2 for interoperability
follows MW_PANEL
use serialVersionUID from JDK 1.2.2 for interoperability
class.javadoc: Event handler for Permission Popup Menu

method.name: itemStateChanged
method.comment: ignore if they choose the 'Permission:' item
if you change the permission, clear the name, actions, and signedBy
set the text in the textfield and also modify the
pull-down choice menus to reflect the correct possible
set of names and actions

class.javadoc: Event handler for UserSaveYes button

method.name: actionPerformed
method.comment: first get rid of the window
the above dialog will continue with the originally
requested command if necessary
save the policy entries to a file
display status
now continue with the originally requested command
(QUIT, NEW, or OPEN)
error -- just report it and bail

this way upon exit we know if to ask the user to save changes

All of the policy entries are read in from the policy file and stored here. Updates to the policy entries using addEntry() and removeEntry() are made here. To ultimately save the policy entries back to the policy file, the SavePolicy button must be clicked.
Parse command line arguments.
split instr to words according to capitalization,
like, AWTControl -> A W T Control
this method is for easy pronounciation
use serialVersionUID from JDK 1.2.2 for interoperability
follows MW_PANEL
use serialVersionUID from JDK 1.2.2 for interoperability
